newsitem.title: USA: US rep queries NRC on nuclear plant fire barriers.
newsitem.headline: US rep queries NRC on nuclear plant fire barriers.

text.p: A House Commerce Committee member on Thursday blasted the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for allowing "flammable fire barriers" in nuclear power plants.
Rep. Ed Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, in a letter to the commission demanded that the NRC justify continued use of the silicone foam substance.
"The notion of using flammable materials as fire barriers in nuclear power plants is as laughable as it is dangerous," Markey said in a statement.
Markey said the substance "is prone to widespread installation problems and defects which reportedly render it useless."
But an NRC spokesman said the substance is useful as a "sacrificial barrier that burns slowly" to give time for sprinkler systems and alarms to come on.
While there have been problems with improper installation of the material, he said the problems have not been with the material itself.
The NRC spokesman also said the material was just part of a complex fire protection system required in nuclear reactors.

But Markey said it was absurd to have a combustible material as a fire barrier, and said it appeared the NRC was "more interested in saving nuclear utilities the expense of replacing this material rather than acting quickly and responsibily to protect the public."
